Load in a dataset that we'll use often.

You can also set custom sizes:

```{r setup}
library(tidyverse)
library(ggridges)
library(patchwork)
```


```{r}
weather_df = 
  rnoaa::meteo_pull_monitors(
    c("USW00094728", "USC00519397", "USS0023B17S"),
    var = c("PRCP", "TMIN", "TMAX"), 
    date_min = "2017-01-01",
    date_max = "2017-12-31") %>%
  mutate(
    name = recode(
      id, 
      USW00094728 = "CentralPark_NY", 
      USC00519397 = "Waikiki_HA",
      USS0023B17S = "Waterhole_WA"),
    tmin = tmin / 10,
    tmax = tmax / 10) %>%
  select(name, id, everything())
```

## Remember this plot... ?

```{r}
weather_df %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = tmin, y = tmax)) + 
  geom_point(aes(color = name), alpha = .5)
``` 

## With Labels

```{r}
weather_df %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = tmin, y = tmax)) + 
  geom_point(aes(color = name), alpha = .5) +
  labs(
    title = "Temp plot",
    x = "Minimum daily temp (C)",
    y = "Maximum daily temperature (C)",
    caption = "Data from the rnoaa package; temps in 2017."
  )
``` 


## Scales

Start with the same plot; x and y scales

```{r}
weather_df %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = tmin, y = tmax)) + 
  geom_point(aes(color = name), alpha = .5) +
  labs(
    title = "Temp plot",
    x = "Minimum daily temp (C)",
    y = "Maximum daily temperature (C)",
    caption = "Data from the rnoaa package; temps in 2017."
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(
    breaks = c(-15, 0, 15),
    labels = c("-15 C", "0", "15")
  )+
  scale_y_continuous(
    position = "right"
  )
``` 


Look at color scales

```{r}
weather_df %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = tmin, y = tmax)) + 
  geom_point(aes(color = name), alpha = .5) +
  labs(
    title = "Temp plot",
    x = "Minimum daily temp (C)",
    y = "Maximum daily temperature (C)",
    caption = "Data from the rnoaa package; temps in 2017."
  ) +
  scale_color_hue(
    name = "Location",
    h = c(100, 300)
  )
``` 


###Virdis

```{r}
ggp_temp_plot = 
  weather_df %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = tmin, y = tmax)) + 
  geom_point(aes(color = name), alpha = .5) + 
  labs(
    title = "Temperature plot",
    x = "Minimum daily temperature (C)",
    y = "Maxiumum daily temperature (C)",
    caption = "Data from the rnoaa package"
  ) + 
  viridis::scale_color_viridis(
    name = "Location", 
    discrete = TRUE
  )

ggp_temp_plot
```


## Themes

Shift the legend 

```{r}
ggp_temp_plot + 
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")
```

Change overall theme

```{r}
ggp_temp_plot + 
  theme_bw() + 
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")
```

```{r}
ggp_temp_plot + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")
```

```{r}
ggp_temp_plot + 
  theme_classic() + 
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")
```

```{r}
ggp_temp_plot + 
  ggthemes::theme_economist() + 
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")
```

```{r}
ggp_temp_plot + 
  ggthemes::theme_excel() + 
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")
```


## Setting options

**Copy paste this into every RMD doc!!**

```{r, eval = FALSE}
library(tidyverse)

knitr::opts_chunk$set(
  fig.width = 6,
  fig.asp = .6,
  out.width = "90%"
)

theme_set(theme_minimal() + theme(legend.position = "bottom"))

options(
  ggplot2.continuous.clour = "viridis",
  ggplot2.continuous.fill = "viridis"
)

sclae_colour_discrete = scale_color_viridis_d()
scale_fill_discrete = scale_fill_viridis_d

```


## Data args in `geom`

```{r}
central_park = 
  weather_df %>% 
  filter(name == "CentralPark_NY")

waikiki = 
  weather_df %>% 
  filter(name == "Waikiki_HA")

ggplot(data = waikiki, aes(x = date, y = tmax, color = name)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  geom_line(data = central_park)
```


## `patchwork`

remember faceting?

```{r}
weather_df %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = tmin, fill = name)) +
  geom_density(alpha = .5) +
  facet_grid(. ~ name)
```

What happens when you want multiple plots but can't facet..?

```{r}
tmax_tmin_p = 
  weather_df %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = tmax, y = tmin, color = name)) + 
  geom_point(alpha = .5) +
  theme(legend.position = "none")

prcp_dens_p = 
  weather_df %>% 
  filter(prcp > 0) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = prcp, fill = name)) + 
  geom_density(alpha = .5) + 
  theme(legend.position = "none")

tmax_date_p = 
  weather_df %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = date, y = tmax, color = name)) + 
  geom_point(alpha = .5) +
  geom_smooth(se = FALSE) + 
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")

(tmax_tmin_p / prcp_dens_p) + tmax_date_p
```

## Data manipulation 

Control your factors.

```{r}
weather_df %>%
  mutate(name = forcats::fct_relevel(name, c("Waikiki_HA", "CentralPark_NY", "Waterhole_WA"))) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = name, y = tmax)) + 
  geom_violin(aes(fill = name), color = "blue", alpha = .5) + 
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")
```

```{r}
weather_df %>%
  mutate(name = forcats::fct_reorder(name, tmax)) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = name, y = tmax)) + 
  geom_violin(aes(fill = name), color = "blue", alpha = .5) + 
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")
```


What if I wanted densities for tmin and tmax simultaneously?

```{r}
weather_df %>% 
  filter(name == "CentralPark_NY") %>% 
  pivot_longer(
    tmax:tmin,
    names_to = "observation",
    values_to = "temperatures"
  ) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = temperatures, fill = observation)) +
  geom_density(alpha=0.5)
```

Separate graphs:

```{r}
weather_df %>% 
  pivot_longer(
    tmax:tmin,
    names_to = "observation",
    values_to = "temperatures"
  ) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = temperatures, fill = observation)) +
  geom_density(alpha=0.5) +
facet_grid(. ~ name)
```
